Sentence-String: Differing results regarding articulation skills in young children with cleft palate (CP) have been reported and often interpreted as a consequence of different surgical protocols.
To assess the influence of different timing of hard palate closure in a two‐stage procedure on articulation skills in 3‐year‐olds born with unilateral cleft lip and palate (UCLP).
Secondary aims were to compare results with peers without CP, and to investigate if there are gender differences in articulation skills.
Furthermore, burden of treatment was to be estimated in terms of secondary surgery, hearing and speech therapy.
A randomized controlled trial (RCT).

Early hard palate closure (EHPC) at 12 months versus late hard palate closure (LHPC) at 36 months in a two‐stage procedure was tested in a cohort of 126 Danish‐speaking children born with non‐syndromic UCLP.
All participants had the lip and soft palate closed around 4 months of age.
Audio and video recordings of a naming test were available from 113 children (32 girls and 81 boys) and were transcribed phonetically.
Recordings were obtained prior to hard palate closure in the LHPC group.
The main outcome measures were percentage consonants correct adjusted (PCC‐A) and consonant errors from blinded assessments.
Results from 36 Danish‐speaking children without CP obtained previously by Willadsen in 2012 were used for comparison.
Children with EHPC produced significantly more target consonants correctly (83%) than children with LHPC (48%; p < .001).
In addition, children with LHPC produced significantly more active cleft speech characteristics than children with EHPC (p < .001).
Boys achieved significantly lower PCC‐A scores than girls (p = .04) and produced significantly more consonant errors than girls (p = .02).
No significant differences were found between groups regarding burden of treatment.
The control group performed significantly better than the EHPC and LHPC groups on all compared variables.
What is already known on the subject

Quite different results have been reported on articulation skills in young children with CP as a consequence of different surgical protocols, or different timings of hard palate closure in two‐stage procedures.
Comparisons between studies are often impossible due to substantial differences in methodologies and methodological flaws.
Most often results on articulation only include cleft speech characteristics that makes it difficult to understand the overall articulation proficiency of the participants.
What this paper adds to existing knowledge

This study of 113 Danish children with UCLP shows that leaving the hard palate unrepaired until 36 months, as opposed to closing it at 12 months of age, has a negative impact on development of articulation skills.
An overall measure of articulation proficiency considering all consonant errors was included to provide a better understanding of the articulation skills of the participants.
Inclusion of a control group of children without CP allowed comparison between articulation skills of 3‐year‐olds with and without CP.
What are the potential or actual clinical implications of this work?
From a linguistic point of view, it is not recommendable to postpone hard palate closure in two‐stage procedures until 36 months of age due to the impact on acquisition of speech sounds.
Results of the present study suggest that it is important to pay attention to all consonant errors in young children with CP, not only those directly related to the cleft condition.
Results also indicate that young boys with CP have poorer articulation than girls do, but further investigation is needed to draw conclusions on clinical implications.
In Denmark, 1.4–1.5 per 1000 children are born with a cleft of the lip with or without cleft palate (CP), and the gender ratio is about 2:1 (male:female) for this cleft type (Christensen et al.
An important treatment goal for many cleft teams is normal speech before school start, which in Denmark is at 6 years of age.
Despite this general agreement, this goal has not yet been reached at the group level even though many individuals acquire normal speech before school start.
Also, there is no convincing evidence of which surgical protocols and perhaps speech interventions that may lead to this goal (e.g., Peterson‐Falzone et al.
As a consequence, consonant errors in children with CP have been an area of investigation for a long time.
Many studies examining consonant errors have focused on the possible relationship between different surgical protocols and speech outcome, including consonant errors.

However, evidence regarding the relationship between surgical protocols and timing is still weak due to methodological shortcomings in many studies, including factors such as large age spans, mixed cleft types and participant selection biases as described in previous reports (e.g., Peterson‐Falzone 2013, Lohmander et al.
To help advancement of research in this field, good practice for speech assessments has been described.

It implies important elements such as analyses based on audio‐recorded speech samples with the use of standardized speech material and recording set up, and assessments being done by blinded raters who are presented with speech material in randomized order (Sell 2005, Britton et al.
From a survey of cleft care in the UK, Bearn et al.
(2001) reported surgical skill as a main factor in achieving good speech outcomes with better results from high‐ versus low‐volume operators.

Recently, results from an international randomized controlled trial (RCT), the Scandcleft Trials, showed that surgeons’ level of experience with a surgical procedure influenced results with a strong surgical learning curve with the use of new techniques (see Rautio et al.
Types of consonant error in cleft palate (CP) speech
Infants with an unrepaired CP start developing their sound inventory in the presence of an oronasal coupling that impacts speech sound acquisition.

It has been consistently found that they produce few speech sounds demanding increased intra‐oral air pressure, i.e., stops, fricatives and affricates, and few coronal sounds as compared with their peers without CP.
Instead, they produce more sounds that are easier for them such as nasals and approximants (e.g., Russell and Grunwell 1993, Chapman et al.
2001, Willadsen and Albrechtsen 2006).
It is well described that prelinguistic utterances, especially canonical syllables, are precursors to speech (e.g., Koopmans‐van Beinum and van der Stelt 1986).

An important element of canonical babbling is learning to master consonant production which is essential for acquisition of early words as these are based on well‐trained canonical syllables (e.g., Stoel‐Gammon and Cooper 1984, Vihman 1992).
The limitations in the early sound inventory of infants with CP are related to the cleft condition and are accordingly phonetic by nature.

However, some toddlers do not change their sound inventory markedly after surgical repair of the CP even in the presence of an adequate velopharyngeal mechanism, and in these cases, the phonetic limitations become integrated into the developing phonological system and change into a phonological disorder (e.g., Russell and Grunwell 1993).
Cleft speech characteristics (CSCs)
‘Cleft speech characteristic’ is a common term for consonant errors related to the cleft condition (e.g., Hutters and Henningsson 2004).
Velopharyngeal dysfunction (VPD), including a residual cleft or a fistula, will necessarily influence speech sound productions.
Consonant errors that occur because of the oronasal coupling are divided into active and passive error types (e.g., Grunwell and Harding 1998).
Active CSCs are consonants with a change in place and/or manner of articulation (Grunwell and Harding 1998, Willadsen et al.
2017) and are regarded as compensatory articulations to avoid consequences of an oronasal coupling.
Active oral CSCs include retracted oral errors where labial, dental, or alveolar target consonants are shifted to a palatal, velar or uvular place of articulation.
Active non‐oral CSCs refer to consonants produced posterior to the oral cavity and include glottal and pharyngeal consonants and active nasal fricatives.

Passive CSCs refer to consonants with an unavoidable change in manner of articulation as a consequence of the oronasal coupling and include nasal emission, loss of aspiration or weak pressure in unvoiced obstruents, or nasalization of voiced consonants.
Influence of cleft type and surgical timing on speech outcomes

Cleft type and cleft extent have been reported to impact articulation skills, and children with isolated clefts of the soft palate only or submucous clefts generally perform better than children with more extensive clefts (e.g., Hardin‐Jones and Jones 2005).
Timing of hard palate closure has also been shown to influence speech results (for an overview, see Lohmander‐Agerskov 1998).
The overall purpose of treatment of children with CP is to achieve good facial growth and speech.
Surgery of the palate will leave scarring which has an adverse effect on facial growth (Friede et al.
1987, Ross 1987), whereas unoperated maxillary clefts are assumed to have near‐normal growth potential.
Therefore, delaying palatal closure until more maxilla growth is completed is a desirable approach from an orthodontic and surgical point of view (Kuijpers‐Jagtman and Long 2000).
However, delayed closure of the hard palate has been described to have a strong negative effect on speech development including articulation (e.g., Holland et al.

Unfortunately, many studies have applied the label delayed hard palate closure to very different techniques and timings of closure of both the soft and the hard palate making it very difficult to compare speech results (e.g., Lohmander‐Agerskov 1998).

In a comprehensive literature review on the evidence of optimal timing of palate closure for normal speech development, Peterson‐Falzone (2013) describes that frequency of VPD following two‐stage procedures can be as low as reported following one‐stage procedures, but articulation is aberrant.
Often, palatal obturators have been used to cover the residual cleft and enhance speech development, but the empirical support for this assumption is weak.

At the same time, there is also no strong evidence of the best timing and procedure for one‐stage palatal closure, although early closure at or before 12 months of age, seems to provide better speech results (Peterson‐Falzone 2013).

The relationship between surgical procedure and timing and normal speech development is further complicated by the previously described differences in methodology for speech documentation (e.g., Sell 2005, Chapman et al.
In two‐stage surgical procedures, the influence of timing of hard palate closure on speech development may expectedly be observed most clearly before the hard palate is closed.
This makes it possible to study how children acquire the speech sounds of their native language in the presence of a repaired velum but with a cleft in the hard palate.

Only two studies have compared articulation skills of 3‐year‐olds with UCLP with soft palate closure at 4–8 months where one group had an unrepaired hard palate at 3 years and another group received hard palate closure at 12 months.

These studies included a total of 26 children, and both reported poorer articulation in children with an unrepaired hard palate compared with children with early hard palate closure (EHPC) including more active CSCs (Willadsen 2012, Klintö et al.
(2006) assessed speech outcome at age 3 in 26 children with UCLP with a similar surgical protocol, and in accordance with Willadsen (2012) and Klintö et al.
(2014b), they found that 3‐year‐olds with an unrepaired cleft in the hard palate showed a high frequency of retracted/backed articulation of anterior obstruents (Lohmander et al.
2006, Willadsen 2012, Klintö et al.
Willadsen (2012) found that only one of 17 children did not produce retracted oral articulations at age 3.

Indeed, articulation skills have been studied in a relatively small number of children (n = 52) with an open hard palate at age 3, and the direct influence of timing of hard palate closure (12 months versus 36 months after speech assessment) has only been studied in 26 children (Willadsen 2012, Klintö et al.
The latter studies reported on a subgroup of Danish and Swedish Scandcleft participants, and bias selection may have occurred as not all randomized participants were included.

Thus, the present study including all available Danish 3‐year‐old Scandcleft participants may extend the present knowledge base due to the relatively high number of participants, the randomization to different timings of hard palate closure and the standardized speech assessments.
Gender differences in articulation skills
Studies of speech sound acquisition in English speakers report girls to be superior to boys (e.g., Smit et al.
2003), but results differ for age groups.
(1990) found significant gender differences at 4;0, 4;6 and 6;0 years, whereas Dodd et al.
(2003) only found significant differences between 5;6 and 7;0 years.

Further, in a large meta‐analysis of gender differences in verbal abilities, Hyde and Linn (1988) reported that effect sizes of female superiority were small and could be considered non‐existing, with the exception of quality of speech production.
In children with CP, gender difference in articulation skills has not been studied thoroughly.
In a longitudinal study following 50 children from 4 to 14 years of age (Hardin et al.
1986), gender was the strongest predictor of speech proficiency at 14 years of age, with female superiority.
Very recently, results of consonant proficiency from 391 five‐year‐olds with UCLP from the Scandcleft Trials including Danish, English, Finnish, Norwegian and Swedish speakers (Willadsen et al.
2017), showed significantly better PCC scores in girls than in boys.
Thus, there is only limited knowledge about possible gender differences in articulation skills of children with CP, and it has not previously been studied in young preschool children.
Percentage of consonants correct adjusted (PCC‐A)
Different ways of reporting articulation outcomes make comparisons between studies difficult.

Indeed, it may be easier to understand an overall score such as the widely used PCC score, originally developed by Shriberg and Kwiatkowski (1982) to assess severity of speech deviation/articulation disorder.
A PCC measure allows direct comparison between children and creates an easily understandable score; the percentage of consonants produced correctly.

Recently, PCC has been recommended as an outcome measure for articulation in cleft care by the International Consortium for Health Outcomes Measurements which aims to recommend measures that matter most to individuals with an orofacial cleft (Allori et al.
The PCC score was originally based on spontaneous speech but has also been widely used for other types of speech samples, such as naming tests also in children with CP (e.g., Scherer et al.
An adjustment of the PCC measure, the PCC‐A, counts as errors omissions, substitutions and uncommon clinical distortions whereas common clinical distortions are not counted as errors (Shriberg et al.
Assessment of articulation skills in children with CP
Articulation skills have been reported in different ways with the use of different speech materials which make direct comparisons between studies impossible.

Some studies only report frequency of CSCs whereas consonant errors that are common in typical language development in younger children, developmental speech characteristics (DSCs), are not addressed (e.g., Lohmander‐Agerskov 1998, Hardin‐Jones and Jones 2005, Britton et al.
Other studies report a percentage of how many children achieved ‘normal articulation’ according to a chosen criterion (e.g., Britton et al.

For these reasons, it is difficult to understand the ‘severity of involvement’ (Shriberg and Kwiatkowski 1982) of a child's articulation difficulties, and different criteria for counting a CSC as present or absent further complicate comparisons.
(2014) count one occurrence of a glottal stop as glottal articulation present, Hardin‐Jones and Jones (2005) use two occurrences as the limit, and Lohmander et al.
(2017) use three occurrences, corresponding to 10% of target sounds, as the minimum to be counted as present.
Danish children start school by age 6, but before that, more than 97% of 3‐year‐olds attend kindergarten (Statistics Denmark n.d.).

Accordingly, poor articulation skills may have a serious impact on their daily life as they have to independently communicate with peers and adults to develop social, pragmatic, and communicative skills.
Therefore, assessing articulation skills in young children with CP is important.
The following questions were addressed:
Do articulation skills at age 3 differ between children with UCLP who received early versus late closure of the hard palate?
How do the participants’ articulation skills compare with peers without CP?
Is there a difference in articulation skills between boys and girls?
The participants were 126 Danish‐speaking Caucasian children with non‐syndromic UCLP born between 1998 and 2007 participating in the Scandcleft Trials (Semb et al.
Children with a soft tissue bridge (Simonart's band) of less than 5 mm were included.
All newly born patients with UCLP were first registered with the study coordinator at the cleft department.
Then the trial coordinator was notified and she used a dice to randomize participants.
She provided an envelope which was opened on the day of the first operation to notify the parents of the timing of subsequent hard palate closure (Semb et al.
Data from 113 participants were available for the data analyses.
Thirteen recordings were missing as two children had not been recorded, seven were unable to cooperate at the assessment and four recordings had a technical failure.

All participants received lip and soft palate closure at 4 months (mean 4.4 months, range 3.8–5.8 months); 55 children had hard palate repair at 1 year (mean 1.04 years, range 0.96–1.34 years); and 58 participants had hard palate repair at 3 years (mean 3.03 years, range 2.91–3.35 years) but always after the 3‐year assessment (see Rautio et al.
2017 regarding the surgical procedure).
Two surgeons performed all first operations and the vast majority of second operations (hard palate closure), which means they were high volume operators (Bearn et al.

The surgeons had experience with a similar procedure before initiation of the trial, and the same surgical procedures were used in both arms as only the timing of hard palate repair differed (Rautio et al.
None of the children was treated with palatal obturators to cover the residual cleft.

Participants were examined by an ear–nose–throat (ENT) specialist within approximately 1 week of the assessment, including visual inspection and tympanometric measurement to assess for otitis media with effusion (OME).
OME causes fluid in the middle ear and may lead to reduced hearing.
The study was approved by the national ethical board and written consent was obtained from all parents.
Secondary pharyngeal surgery and palatal fistulae
No child had undergone secondary pharyngeal surgery before 3 years, and only one child in the EHPC group had a fistula repaired before the 3‐year assessment.

This means that no child in the EHPC group had an open fistula at the time of the 3‐year assessment; the open hard palate in the participants in the late hard palate closure (LHPC) group was not counted as a fistula.
Unfortunately, only a minor number of children had their hearing tested, and due to lack of data, comparison between groups was impossible.
Instead, ear status, including tympanometry referred to as normal condition or not, and presence or absence of pressure equalizing tubes (PET) is reported in table 1.
Number of children (%) with pressure equalizing tubes (PET)/otitis media with effusion (OME)/normal condition in one or two ears or missing information in the participating groups
Total number of speech therapy visits up to 3 years was collected for all children, including clinical follow‐up visits at the cleft department and therapy sessions in the local community.
Only two children had received direct speech therapy before age three; 11 sessions each.

The local therapy was described as mainly non‐speech oral motor exercises, although the literature in general suggests there is no evidence to support the efficacy of non‐speech oral motor exercises (e.g., Forrest 2002).
The individual number of visits at the team speech–language pathologist/therapist (SLP/T) and the local SLP/T are summarized in table 2.
Mean number of speech visits at the team and local SLP/T in the EHPC and LHPC groups

At 36 months (mean 3.0 years, range 2.83–3.23 years), all participants were audio‐ and video‐recorded performing a naming test, developed by the Scandcleft speech group, at one of two Danish CP centres.

Thirty target words with three representations of each of 10 target sounds (/p t k b d g f s n v/) in word‐initial position, except for /s/ in word final position, were selected according to criteria such as the phonetic context and age appropriateness (Lohmander et al.
Target words were tested both clinically and in 35 typically developing children before they were finally decided.
Two dummies familiarized the child with the task.
If the child did not name a picture, a semantic cue was given; secondly, he/she was asked to repeat the word after the investigator.
Results include both spontaneous namings and repetitions.
The SLP/Ts who transcribed data in the present study were all involved in the Scandcleft Trials and had taken part in phonetic transcription training (Willadsen et al.
An additional training module of 12 h was undertaken before data analysis in this study.
Recordings were edited to present one target word at a time, and each naming test was split into two files of 15 words each.
Listeners watched each video clip on a computer.
They wore high‐quality headphones and could re‐listen limitlessly.
Listeners transcribed target consonants in narrow phonetic transcription according to the international phonetic alphabet (IPA) and extended IPA.
For two children, one from each group, assessments were done from audio recordings as video recordings had a technical failure.
Classification of target realizations of the naming test
When all transcriptions were performed, the first author categorized all consonant errors according to criteria specified below.
A research assistant went through all classifications, and discrepancies were solved according to the predetermined rules.
First, a target sound was assessed regarding manner and place of articulation.
If incorrect, the target realization was classified as either a CSC and/or a DSC.
The CSCs were classified according to the Scandcleft procedure (Lohmander et al.
2009) and are presented in table 3.
The term ‘insufficient closure between the oral and nasal cavity’ refers to passive CSCs regarded as the consequence of oronasal coupling, either due to VPD or a residual cleft in the hard palate.
Fronting, stopping, deaspiration or aspiration, and f/v substitutions were classified as DSCs (Hutters et al.
A few errors did not fit into these categories and were classified as ‘other’ under DSCs.
Classification of CSCs used in the present study
Ninety target realizations were classified as both DSCs and CSCs, e.g., target [f] realized as [k], i.e., backing (CSC) and stopping (DSC).
A target realization could maximally be affected by one active and one passive CSC, e.g., [f] realized as [k͋], i.e., backing (active oral CSC) and nasal emission (passive CSC).
Percentage of consonants correct adjusted (PCC‐A score)

A target realization was correct if manner and place of articulation were correct, also in cases of audible consequences of insufficient closure between the oral and nasal cavity, as long as the child's production did not cross a phoneme boundary (e.g., [f] realized as [f͋]).

Age appropriate clinical distortions were counted as correct and include: s‐sounds with a dental, inter‐dental or post‐alveolar place of articulation, laminal articulation of coronal sounds (/d t/), and bilabial articulation of /f v/.
Inter‐ and intra‐rater agreement
Four Danish SLP/Ts involved in the Scandcleft Trials assessed the speech material.
In Denmark, all primary surgeries are performed at Rigshospitalet in Copenhagen, but the patients are followed up at one of two centres in the western and eastern part.
Seventy‐nine children were assessed in the present study, and all SLP/Ts analyzed participants from another centre.
Thus, participants and randomization were unknown to the SLP/Ts who had also not been involved in their treatment.
Two transcribers evaluated 38 children from Copenhagen and two transcribers evaluated 41 children from Aarhus.
In addition, 20% of the files were randomly selected and reduplicated for intra‐rater agreement.
Folders of 15 word files were created and randomized such that at least 10 different children were evaluated before a second file of the same child reappeared.
Intra‐rater agreement for the listeners is shown in table 4.
Intra‐rater agreement scores (%) for the four listeners
Interrater agreement was not assessed as consensual listening was used.
Transcriptions were compared point by point and all disagreements were re‐evaluated by the two listeners who had first transcribed them, and a listener from the other ‘team’.
Disagreements were solved by majority decision.
Regarding the 34 participants with CP evaluated in the previous study (Willadsen 2012), identical recording procedures and materials were used as all were Scandcleft participants.
The control group included in Willadsen (2012) formed part of a Danish subproject to the Scandcleft Trials with the purpose of comparing speech results of children without CP.
Therefore, the control group was assessed in the same way as the Scandcleft participants.
Willadsen did not use consensus listening.
Instead, the author transcribed all naming tests, and another SLP/T transcribed 20% of these.
Good inter‐ and intra‐rater agreement was found.
The author (Willadsen 2012) was employed at the cleft department, had done most of the recordings and knew the randomization of the participants but was not involved in any treatment.
The second transcriber was external, blinded to randomization, and did not know the participants.
Classification of consonant errors had been done in the same way as in the present study, except for assessment of /s/ qualities (Willadsen 2012).
Accordingly, all /s/ targets were reclassified according to the principles of the present study.
Differences between listener groups
We were concerned that a difference might exist in the assessments between listeners from the two centres as well as from the previous study (Willadsen 2012).
However, the distribution between participants allocated to the EHPC and LHPC groups was quite similar, as seen in table 5, and accordingly, the PCC‐A scores of the three datasets were compared.
A Kruskal–Wallis test revealed no significant difference between the PCC‐A scores in the different centres and the previous study (H(2) = 1.768, p = .413).
Therefore, all data were pooled, and the following presentation includes data from all 113 Danish participants.
Distribution of participants in the EHPC and LHPC groups in Copenhagen, Aarhus and the previous study (Willadsen 2012)
Descriptives were calculated, and differences between groups were compared for each variable.
Non‐parametric statistics were used due to skewed distributions.
Univariate analyses were performed for comparisons between outcome measures and independent variables.
A significance level of p < .05 was used.
For post‐hoc analyses, pairwise comparisons were used, and significance values have been adjusted with Bonferroni corrections for multiple tests.
Due to their young age, many participants did not name all pictures, and we were concerned that a difference in number of pictures named might influence the results.
Post‐hoc pairwise comparisons of groups revealed no significant difference between the EHPC and LHPC groups regarding number of words not named (Z = 1.00, p = .39).
However, it was possible that results from children who named relatively few pictures influenced the overall results.
Accordingly, measures that showed significant differences between the groups were reanalyzed excluding children who named fewer than half the pictures (≤ 15).
This meant exclusion of two children from the EHPC group and 10 children from the LHPC group.
Table 6 shows medians and 25th and 75th percentiles of these measures, including all children and excluding children who named fewer than 15 pictures.
As shown in table 6, only small differences were observed in the Z‐values with no effect on the level of significance between the groups.
Likewise, only minor changes were observed in the medians and the 25th and 75th percentiles, and therefore all children were kept in the data analyses.
PCC‐A scores calculated with and without children who named 15 pictures or fewer
The PCC‐A score was calculated as the percentage of pictures with correctly produced target consonants of the total number of pictures named.
Box plots of PCC‐A scores in the compared groups are shown in figure 1 with medians and 25th and 75th percentiles.
Whiskers show extreme values with outliers > 1.5 box widths from the median separately.
A Kruskal–Wallis one‐way analysis of variance (ANOVA) revealed a significant difference between the compared groups for median PCC‐A scores (H(2), 89.37, n = 147, p < .001).

Post‐hoc pairwise comparisons showed that the LHPC group achieved significantly lower median PCC‐A scores (48.3%) than the EHPC group (83.1%) (Z = –6.43, n = 113, p < .001), and the control group achieved significantly higher median PCC‐A scores (96.7%) than the LHPC and EHPC groups, respectively (LHPC: Z = –7.80, n = 90, p < .001; EHPC: Z = –6.24, n = 93, p < .001).

Figures 2a and 2b show the distribution of children in the compared groups who achieved a PCC‐A score corresponding to or better than the lowest score obtained by a control child (83.3%), as well as the percentage of children with a PCC‐A score of 50% or lower.
A Fisher's exact test showed that the distribution of PCC‐A levels differed significantly between the groups at both levels (PCC‐A ≥ 83.3%: p < .001; PCC‐A ≥ 50%: p < .001).

As shown in table 7, follow‐up Fisher's exact tests revealed that significantly more children in the control group achieved a PCC‐A score of at least 83.3% than children in the LHPC and EHPC groups, respectively.
In addition, significantly fewer children in the LHPC group achieved a PCC‐A score of 83.3% than children in the EHPC group.
The difference between percentage of children in the control group and the EHPC group who achieved a PCC‐A score of 50% or lower was not significant.
In contrast, significantly more children in the LHPC group obtained a PCC‐A score of 50% or lower than the children in the EHPC group and in the control group.
(a) Percentage of children with a PCC‐A‐score as high as or better than the lowest score in the Control group (83.3%).
(b) Percentage of children with a PCC‐A score of 50% or lower in the compared groups.
Differences in PCC‐A levels between the three compared groups
Developmental speech characteristics (DSCs)
Table 8 shows descriptives of median percentage of DSCs in the compared groups.
A Kruskal–Wallis one‐way ANOVA revealed a significant difference between the three compared groups (H(2) = 32.54, n = 147, p < .001).

Post‐hoc pairwise comparisons of groups showed a significant difference between percentage of DSCs between the control group and the LHPC group (Z = –5.48, n = 89, p < .001), and between the control group and the EHPC group (Z = –4.64, n = 92, p < .001).
The difference between the EHPC and LHPC groups was not significant (Z = –1.17, n = 147, p < .24).

Nor did the LHPC and EHPC groups differ significantly regarding percentage of children producing 10% or more DSCs (p = .30), whereas significantly fewer children in the control group produced 10% or more DSCs than children in the LHPC group (p < .001) and in the EHPC group (p < .001), respectively.
Medians, 25th and 75th percentiles, and percentage of children who produced 10% or more DSCs in the EHPC, LHPC and control groups
Cleft speech characteristics (CSCs)
This measure only concerns children with CP.
As shown in table 9, a Pearson chi‐square test revealed that significantly more children in the LHPC group produced 10% or more active CSCs than in the EHPC group (χ2 = 35.45, n = 113, p < .001).
The most frequent CSC is backing/retraction to palatal/velar/uvular place of articulation.
Also, significantly more children in the LHPC group produced 10% or more retracted/backed articulations than children in the EHPC group (p < .001).

In addition, significantly more children in the LHPC group replaced 10% or more oral obstruents by nasal consonants than in the EHPC group (p < .001), and significantly more children in the LHPC group produced active nasal fricatives compared with the EHPC group (p = .021).
Percentage of children producing 10% or more CSCs in the EHPC and LHPC groups
The differences between the groups were non‐significant for replacements of obstruents by /h/ or by glottal stop and omission of target consonant.
Ninety target realizations were classified as both CSCs and DSCs errors, and 87 of these were produced by children in the LHPC group.
Gender differences across the LHPC and EHPC groups
A Mann–Whitney test revealed that girls achieved significantly higher PCC‐A scores than boys (Z = –2.03, n = 113, p = .042).

Replacement of obstruent by /h/ was also produced significantly more frequently by boys than girls (Z = –2.1, n = 113, p = .035), and boys produced significantly more errors than girls (Z = –2.25, n = 113, p = .024).

The purpose of the present study was to examine the influence of timing of hard palate closure on articulation skills at 3 years in 113 children with UCLP treated with a two‐stage procedure with hard palate closure at either 12 or 36 months of age; the residual cleft was unoperated at the 3‐year speech assessment.
Speech materials and assessment procedures were standardized (Lohmander et al.
2017), and naming tests were transcribed independently by two trained external SLP/Ts who were blinded to randomization.
The primary finding was that children in the EHPC group had significantly better articulation skills than children in the LHPC group.
In the following, only statistically significant differences are discussed unless otherwise specified.
Comparisons between the EHPC and LHPC groups

The influence of timing of hard palate closure on overall articulation proficiency in children with UCLP at 3 years, treated according to a surgical protocol comparable with the present study, was investigated by Klintö et al.

They reported higher PCC‐A scores in the group with earlier hard palate closure (12 months) compared with a group with an unrepaired hard palate at 3 years, but the difference was not statistically significant.
According to the authors, the lack of statistical difference between the groups may be due to small sample sizes, with only nine participants in each group.

The previous study by Willadsen (2012) reported that 3‐year‐olds with hard palate closure at 12 months (n = 17) achieved significantly higher PCC scores than the group with an unrepaired hard palate (n = 17).

The finding in the latter studies may however have been influenced by inclusion of only a subgroup of the participants in the Scandcleft Trials and might therefore not be representative for the entire group.
However, the present finding strongly supports the results from these previous studies (Willadsen 2012, Klintö et al.
Comparisons with children without CP

Studies comparing overall articulation skills between children with and without CP found that 3‐year‐olds with CP have significantly poorer articulation skills than their age‐matched peers (Bzoch 1965, Hutters et al.
2001, Willadsen 2012, Klintö et al.
2014b), even in younger children (Scherer et al.
These findings are consistent even though studies differ with respect to inclusion of children with different one‐ and two‐stage protocols, different and mixed cleft types, and speech material used.
Therefore, more in‐depth comparisons are not possible.
A modified PCC‐A score was used in this study.
We did not count as errors target sounds realized incorrectly according to the adult model if these realizations are known to occur among typically developing children.
As an example, Danish alveolars are coronal, but in this study laminal articulation of alveolars was counted as correct because it also occurred in the control group.
Furthermore, type of speech material for elicitation of speech samples has been shown to influence speech results.
(2011) found that single word naming showed the best performance of children with CP over sentence repetition and spontaneous speech.
As a consequence, the PCC‐A score in the present study may be regarded as best‐case scenario for the participants.

This highlights the poor results of children with CP as compared with their peers without CP, especially in the LHPC group where only two of the children achieved a PCC‐A score that was as good as or better than the control child with the lowest score (83.3%), whereas this was the case for half the children in the EHPC group.
Furthermore, only three children (5%) in the EHPC group achieved a PCC‐A score of 50% or worse, whereas this accounted for 29 children (53%) in the LHPC group.
The significance of this finding is underlined by the main articulation outcomes of trial 1 in the Scandcleft Trials (Willadsen et al.
At 5 years of age children treated with hard palate closure at age 3 still achieved significantly lower PCC‐A scores than children who had had hard palate closure at 1 year.
Accordingly, delaying closure of the hard palate until age 3 has a long lasting negative effect on articulation skills in children with UCLP.
Compared with their typically developing peers, children with CP made more consonant errors which may influence intelligibility of speech (e.g., Shriberg et al.
Willadsen and Poulsen (2012) examined intelligibility in 28 of the 3‐year‐olds with UCLP and 14 control children from the previous study (Willadsen 2012).

Willadsen and Poulsen (2012) included 84 naïve listeners who heard two presentations of each target word from the naming test as used in the present study and were instructed to write down the word they heard.
Results showed a very high positive correlation between PCC scores of the participants and how well listeners understood their target words (r = .91, p < .001).

Even though single word naming cannot measure a child's communication ability, it does imply that speech intelligibility is affected by consonant errors as reported in many studies (e.g., Lousada et al.
Cleft speech characteristics (CSCs)
CSCs occurred more often in the LHPC group than in the EHPC group.
In the LHPC group 54/55 children realized 10% or more target consonants as an active CSC, as opposed to 18/58 children in the EHPC group.
Backing/retraction was the most frequent active CSC in both cleft groups; again, more children in the LHPC group (71%) than in the EHPC group (16%) produced 10% or more retracted oral articulations.
This finding is in agreement with results reported by Klintö et al.
(2014a) who found that 3‐year‐olds with an unrepaired hard palate produced more retracted articulations than those with hard palate closure at 12 months.

A high frequency of retracted oral articulation has been reported consistently in the literature on delayed hard palate closure with velar closure before 1 year and an unrepaired hard palate at 3 years.

Two Swedish publications have reported that 45–80% of 3‐year‐olds with UCLP, treated with a similar two‐stage procedure, use retracted oral articulation ‘often to always’ with ‘often’ based on an ordinal scale where ‘often’ is defined as more than two occurrences in the speech sample (Lohmander‐Agerskov 1998, Lohmander et al.
However, these studies did not include children with earlier hard palate closure.

Retracted oral articulation is regarded as unrelated to VPD as the child is capable of building up intra‐oral air pressure behind the cleft in the hard palate (e.g., Lohmander‐Agerskov 1998, Willadsen 2012).
Furthermore, it can be assumed that the high occurrence of active CSCs is not a consequence of a possible high VPD rate since passive CSCs occurred at similar rates in the two groups with CP.
This assumption is further supported by a low occurrence of glottal stops and glottal fricatives and absence of pharyngeal articulations in both groups with CP.
Children in the LHPC group produced more active nasal fricatives than children in the EHPC group.
Active nasal fricatives have been described as a compensatory articulation in the presence of VPD (e.g., Peterson‐Falzone et al.

However, active nasal fricatives are also known to occur in speech development of typically developing children, as well as it may occur in children with CP in the presence of a competent velopharyngeal mechanism, i.e., as a functional disorder (e.g., Peterson‐Falzone et al.

Another possible explanation is that the presence of an opening in the anterior hard palate makes learning to produce an alveolar sibilant more difficult than for children with an intact hard palate surface.

Due to the age of the children, it is not possible to determine how this finding is better explained, but the frequency of active nasal fricatives was relatively low in both groups, though higher in the LHPC group.

In summary, the low occurrence of non‐oral CSCs (glottal and pharyngeal articulations and active nasal fricatives) suggests that the poor articulation skills in especially the LHPC group is not related to VPD but rather to the presence of an unrepaired hard palate at the time when the children are acquiring the sound system of their language(s).
Presence of an open hard palate may impact speech sound development for different reasons.

First, the lack of an intact alveolar surface for articulation practice and the different kinesthetic feedback from this, make acquisition of alveolars especially difficult (e.g., Chapman and Willadsen 2011).

Second, auditory feedback from attempted anterior obstruents is different because of the inability to create sufficient intra‐oral air pressure, often resulting in accompanying nasal air escape or nasalization of voiced sounds.
The ability to impound intra‐oral air pressure behind the residual cleft is the assumed reason for retracted/backed articulations (Lohmander‐Agerskov 1998, Willadsen 2012).

Third, knowledge of speech sound production develops during the early years, including motoric patterns for articulatory movements, and compensatory articulations may become integrated into the rules‐based system for speech sound production (e.g., Grunwell 1993).
Developmental speech characteristics (DSCs)

Many researchers have suggested that poor articulation skills in young children with CP are not only related to the cleft condition but also to a delay in speech development (e.g., Chapman and Hardin 1992, Hutters et al.
(2001) reported a higher frequency of DSCs in children with CP compared with their peers without CP which is in agreement with the present study.

2014a suggested that a finding of fewer spontaneous namings by children with CP than by their peers without CP might indicate a delay in speech and language development suggestive of a smaller expressive vocabulary.

Similarly, this study showed a difference between groups for number of pictures named as children in the control group named more pictures than children with CP, with no difference between the latter groups.

Accordingly, the present study lends support to a possible delay in speech and language development at age 3 in children with UCLP at the group level, and the delay seems related to the cleft condition rather than a difference in timing of hard palate closure.
As suggested by Hutters et al.
(2001), speech delay may be attributed partly to the cleft condition as practice and feedback are essential for typical speech development (e.g., Menn and Stoel‐Gammon 1995, Vihman 1992).
This assumption is further supported by recent research on the role of production practice in lexical and phonological development by Vihman and Keren‐Portnoy (2011).
They showed that vocal practice affects word learning and phonological memory in typically developing children and summarized that ‘production experience does indeed support phonological memory.

More specifically, we found that the length of time over which a child has been producing consonants correlates positively with success in non‐word repetition, the usual index of phonological working memory’ (p. 44).
In the present study, boys produced fewer consonants correctly than girls at 3 years.

Gender differences in articulation skills of young children with CP have to our knowledge not been reported until recently when results of consonant proficiency from 391 five‐year‐olds with UCLP from the Scandcleft Trials (Willadsen et al.
2017) showed a significant difference in PCC scores (s‐errors excluded), with girls achieving higher PCC scores than boys.
However, gender was reported as the strongest predictor of speech proficiency at 14 years of age in a longitudinal study of 50 children with UCLP from 4 to 14 years of age (Hardin et al.
A gender difference in articulation accuracy has also been reported for typically developing preschool children at 4–5 years rather than at 3 years (e.g., Dodd et al.

In a large meta‐analysis of gender differences in verbal ability, Hyde and Linn (1988) reported no differences except for speech accuracy where girls performed better than boys; however, no information on age was provided.
One explanation for the gender differences described in these studies is that fine motor skills develop faster in girls than boys (Dodd et al.
Also, more boys than girls show speech disabilities (e.g., Shriberg et al.
1999), and this led Willadsen et al.
(2017) to suggest that boys may be more hindered by their structural deficit than girls.
This suggestion might also explain the higher number of total consonant errors in boys than girls in this study.
Influence of hearing, speech therapy and secondary surgery
As hearing data were not available for the majority of children, information on ear status was reported and revealed overall similarity between the LHPC and EHPC group.
Unfortunately, the lack of hearing data makes it impossible to investigate a possible influence of hearing on speech outcomes.
However, systematic differences in hearing between the two groups are not expected due to randomization and large number of participants.
In addition, all participants had velar closure around 4 months of age according to the same surgical protocol that was performed by one of two surgeons (Rautio et al.

This means that the reported differences in speech outcomes between groups can most probably not be explained by a difference in hearing between the two groups, but it may likely influence speech outcomes in some individuals.
The total number of speech visits was very similar between the groups, and only two children, one from each group, had received speech therapy.
Accordingly, number of speech visits cannot explain group differences observed in speech outcomes.

Furthermore, as no child had received secondary surgery for VPD, and no child had a palatal fistula at the time of the speech assessment, disregarding the intended open hard palate in the LHPC group, none of these factors explains the different speech outcomes observed in the LHPC and EHPC group.
At 3 years, the burden of treatment was very similar between the LHPC and EHPC group.
This study had a high participation rate (113/126), but due to the age of the participants, many were not able to name all pictures, which may have influenced the results.
However, there was no difference in number of pictures named between the EHPC and LHPC groups.

A standardized setting for recording was used, but in some instances the sound quality was affected by adults speaking at the same time or external noise, and a total of 33 target words were excluded due to noise.
Unfortunately, hearing data were missing for many participants, and so it was not possible to examine the possible influence of hearing levels on articulation skills.
In addition, data on ear status were mostly collected from local ENTs which means that procedures and judgments may have differed.
However, very similar results for ear status were observed in both groups with CP.

Data from 34 participants in a previous study (Willadsen 2012) had been analyzed earlier by one SLP/T, and 20% were transcribed by an external SLP/T for interrater reliability, whereas the 77 remaining participants were transcribed by two external SLP/Ts.
This may have influenced the results.
However, no significant differences were found between the PCC scores in the two studies, and the distribution of children into the EHPC and LHPC groups was similar.

Blinded assessments of naming tests from 113 Danish 3‐year‐olds with UCLP, randomized for hard palate closure at 12 or 36 months of age, showed that children with an unrepaired hard palate at the time of the 3‐year assessment had significantly poorer articulation skills than children who had received hard palate closure at 12 months of age.
An open hard palate in 3‐year‐olds acquiring the speech sounds of their native language has a strong negative effect on their articulatory skills.
Both groups of children with UCLP produced significantly fewer consonants correctly than their peers without CP, and boys with UCLP obtained significantly lower PCC‐A scores than girls with UCLP.
At 3 years no difference was found in burden of treatment between the groups regarding ear status, number of speech therapy lessons, or secondary pharyngeal surgery received.
